summary: This is an FBI/NYPD operations order form detailing the planned arrest of Jeffrey Epstein at Teterboro Airport on July 6, 2019, and the subsequent search of his New York City residence. It includes personnel assignments, location surveys, and the FBI deadly force policy.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The primary target of the arrest operation. Document notes his criminal record as a registered sex offender and his scheduled return to the US via Teterboro Airport.

connections.description: Osborn is the overall commander of the operation to arrest Epstein.
Watson is an on-scene commander for the operation to arrest Epstein.
Picarello is an on-scene commander for the operation to arrest Epstein.
Both are FBI commanders assigned to the same arrest operation.
Both are on-scene commanders (FBI and NYPD) for the same arrest operation.

events.title: Planned Arrest of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Epstein was scheduled to return to the US via Teterboro Airport at 5:20 PM. Upon arrival, CBP was to detain him, followed by FBI and NYPD agents effecting his arrest. A search warrant for his New York residence was to be sworn out after his custody.

events.title: Epstein's Florida Guilty Plea
events.description: Epstein pled guilty to one count of solicitation of prostitution and one count of solicitation of prostitution with a minor, resulting in his status as a registered sex offender.

locations: Teterboro Airport (111 Industrial Ave, Teterboro, NJ 07068)
9 East 71st Street, New York, New York
New York Presbyterian/Cornell Medical Center (525 East 68th Street at York Avenue, Manhattan)
University Medical Center New Jersey - University Hospital (150 Bergen Street, Newark, New Jersey)
19th Precinct, NYPD (153 East 67th Street, New York, NY)
keyFacts: The document is a detailed operations order for the arrest of Jeffrey Epstein planned for July 6, 2019, upon his return to the US via Teterboro Airport.

The operation involved a large, coordinated team from the FBI, NYPD, and CBP, with plans to immediately execute a search warrant at Epstein's New York City mansion at 9 East 71st Street following his arrest.
Epstein's criminal record is noted as a registered sex offender due to his 2008 guilty plea in Florida for solicitation of prostitution and solicitation of prostitution with a minor.
The document includes contingency planning, such as designated hospitals (New York Presbyterian and University Hospital in Newark) and the NYPD's 19th Precinct for notifications.
The final page reiterates the FBI's deadly force policy, indicating the operation considered the potential for armed resistance.
